To the Editor: Regarding ''Airlines Put Passengers on Forced Diets'' (Feb. 10): To heck with airlines' gelatinous pasta and so-called beef meals. To heck also with airports' greasy fast food. Just give us room to have a picnic!
On a five-hour flight to Kauai from Los Angeles, I pulled out black bread, smoked salmon and cream cheese, just as the guy in front pushed his seat back to the max, and into my face.

Trapped in front and hemmed in on both sides, I doggedly laid out my smorgasbord. Before I could take a bite, my window seatmate squirted me in the eye while peeling an orange, and the man on the aisle opened his paper with a flourish that sent my sandwich skidding into my lap.

The flight attendants lumbered up with the drinks cart long after I'd choked down the last dry pumpernickel crumb. My water bottle (at my feet in a carry-on) was inaccessible thanks to the intrusive seat back.
If the airlines ceased to serve their awful meals, they could use the monetary savings to give us enough elbow room to feed ourselves.
